thony's Son with her—weary of his Company—Come, Gentlemen, let's fly where Love commands, and ſo much Beauty waits.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I feel unuſual Motions at my heart, 'tis hard to ſay—between two different Paſſions which of them reigns with greateſt Power. Love and Fear divide my Soul, and whirl my Blood through this diſorder'd frame.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'i take care to comfort you with Timandra's Preſence; I hope, Capt. you have no ſuch Love-qualms at your heart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No faith, I go to find my Miſtreſs with that chearfulneſs with which I've encountred my Enemies when Martial heat and honour ſpurr'd me on.

q.l: Courage in Love has often brought ſucceſs;
Levell'd the Way for wiſh'd-for Happineſs.
The Canting, Whining Fool, young Maids deſpiſe,
Whoſe only Courtſhip in his Silence lies;
Love, like our Wine, ſhou'd ſparkle in our Eyes.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: WEll, Young man, you are very welcome; my Neice ſhall receive you like the Son of Sir Anthony Addle.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, I like that Speech very well—but by Ovid I know not what to ſay to her; for tho', upon occaſion, I can let my Sir-father ſee my Parts, and that his Money is well beſtow'd upon me in the Univerſity, yet to ſpeak to a young Lady, and a Stranger too—Why, I can no more do it, than go to bed without my Supper, or ſay my Prayers at night without falling aſleep.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Come, come, no matter for that, the Woman knows your Errand: bear up to her briskly, the baggage loves a confident thund'ring Lover, that deal his Oaths by dozens.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: A thund'ring Lover, that deals his Oaths by dozens—By Priam I'll fit her for that: Hem—hem—let me ſee—ay, I have it—Mum Dick [Enter Timand: ſhe comes—now boy prepare, 'tis a lovely Wench by Jupiter—Madam—by Ovid I've almoſt forget my Complement—but ſtay, I muſt ſalute her firſt—Madam, let the Cannon of my Sighs batter down the Walls of your Reſolutions, that my Love may ride in Triumph through the Streets of your heart, and diſplay the Colours of my ſincere affections over the—Uds ſo, my Memory will betray me—over the—why Madam—why Madam, over your Beauty—I'm a Beau.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: An Eloquent declaration of Love I muſt confeſs, and ſpoke like a Man juſt arrived from the Siege of Namure.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Madam, why I came but to Town laſt night, or this morning early from the Univerſity, where we only fight for bloody Noſes, or ſo, and ſcale the Walls of a ſtately Pye—'tis a handſom Coat.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And were your Cloaths made at the Univerſity? Sir, you look like a handſom Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: No, Madam, my honourable Sir-father brought them ready-made in Long-Lane; he's a very Wiſe man, Madam, tho' I ſay't that ſhou'd not ſay't; and yet I know no reaſon why a man may not commend the Wiſdom of his own Father.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I preſume he may be wiſe, for he has dealt little of his Wilt to his Son.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, your Ladiſhip is merry with your humble Servant—But uds ſo, I forget my thund'ring Complements: Madam, my heart (like Tinder) took fire from—what?—took fire from the firſt ſparkle your fair Eyes darted upon me; by this Light I love ye; by this Right-hand I doat upon ye; by Plato and Ariſtotle—I dye for ye, and—the Waſtcoat too is of an exact length.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Dye for me, Sir! Sure ye wou'd not rob the World of its beſt Jewel!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, that's true, I'm handſom, and the World is pleas'd to eſteem me, and ſo forth: but as I was ſaying, Madam, dye for ye—why, I'd fight for ye, and that's more, if ye conſider I'm a Beau.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How, Sir! wou'd Beaus rather dye than ſight?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, he wou'd rather be kickt to death twenty times, than run to death with a ſmall Sword once; but by Juno I'll box over a Hat with Samſon for ye; and 'tis a bloody dog, Madam, I warrant him; why, he c • n handle a Drey-horſe like a Paper-kite; I can dance too, Madam, Tal-la-ra, ta-fa-la—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Siſter—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Lincolns-Inn-Fields! by Vulcan I heard that.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And d'ye feel that? Imprimis, So much for ill manners. Ditto, to cure your madneſs.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, your humble Servant, Sir; but by Ovid I don't love your Bills, tho' of few Articles; beat a Knight's Son! Uds ſo, the King ſhall hear on't, that he ſhall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Are Sir Anthony's Daughters there?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, I juſt now came from them, after my promiſe to return in ſix minutes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Lead the way then, I'll follow—your humble Servant Sir, I hope you'll eaſily pardon that Affront the Gentleman put upon you; 'twas but a Jeſt, and Beaus, ſuch as you are, commonly have ſuch pretty Jeſts put upon them.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Have they? Uds ſo, I'll never be a Beau again then; by Pan I courted very handſomly till that Raſcal came in; I never ſhall forget his Impudence; I've a good mind now to ſend him a Challenge that I may cut his Throat civilly, like a modern Chriſtian: but hang that Thought, Tyburn ſtares me in the face already; my Sir-father ſhall ſee him fin'd ſome hundreds of pounds, impriſon'd till payment, and oblig'd to find bail for his good behaviour for the future; there wou'd be no living if there were not Law for ſuch Rogues to bind them to the Peace.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: How now? where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Niece!

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, my Niece, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid, as the Latin Saying is—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: I'll have none of your gabling ſtrange ſtuff; I'll have nothing to do with Latin, no, not I; I ſay, where's Timandra? where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why there was a damn'd ſort of a fellow, I think he's her Brother, at leaſt he call'd her Siſter; but every Woman may be ſo to him for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, and what of him? 'tis Ned; 'tis that young Villain, 'tis; and I'll be reveng'd, a knave: well, go on.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: And ſo, Sir, in he comes—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: It muſt be he, that's certain; the graceleſs young dog is ſtill at a miſchief.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, it muſt be he then, for he was at a miſchief upon ſight.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What, he?—whom d'ye mean?—but go on; what was he that came in?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: The Devil, Sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Then 'twas Ned; 'twas my ſweet Nephew; wou'd the Rogue were fai • ly hang'd; I muſt be rid of him, that's certain.—Well, and what ſay you to this, Young-man? what ſay you to't—To what?—Why, Sirrah; wou'd you pretend Ignorance? wou'd you—Yes Sir.—Yes, Sir! why look ye now friend, thus I'll teach you your duty, thus, Sirrah:—Mercy, Sir; I beg your Pardon: No mercy, no pardon you dog; I'll have every bone in your skin broke, ſirrah; ay, I will—I will—you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo; 'tis my ſafeſt courſe to remove my body from this place; 'tis a mad dangerous Family, and this Old Curmudgeon may be upon me with a new Bill of Imprimi • 's and Ditto's worſe than the former: good buye, Sir, good buye—Uds ſo, let me ſee; I won't loſe my Miſtreſs, I'll follow to the Walks.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, and what did the Rogue when he came in? what was't he ſaid?—Why, this young fellow is gone too—Ned has prevail'd upon him to affront me; I'll go and ſeek the Raſcal immediately, and if I catch him—a—Villian—a—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe bid me ſtay in this Room till ſhe came—Was it not ſo?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaut a deel Sir aur ye deef, ſhoe baud ye tarry here aun no gang awau till ſhe caum benn.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ben—but 'tis no matter; Willie, you muſt forget Scotland, and conform yourſelf to the Cuſtoms of England; learn our Accent.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau Sir, ſheam fau me thaun, Cuſtoms o Englaun quo? Nau, nau, I'ſe do aus our Meaſt Johoan does pray for yer reformaution in good-bred Scots. Aus for yer accent Sir, I ſpeak as Father Audaum ſpauke before me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Then Adam ſpoke Scotch?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun thaut he did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But to the purpoſe; to render you a compleat Servant, obſerve theſe three things; keep a due diſtance; ſpeak little, and hear much.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Waud ye learn au Gentleman good manners?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, doſt thou pretend to quality?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul do I Sir, we Scotlaun Lauds aur au Gentlemen whun we come tea Englaun, thee Waulſh aun Iriſh aur neathing tea us for quality.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That's good; but remember when the Old Gentlewoman enters, you muſt be ſilent as a Mute; 'tis ſhe that helps me to the Rich Lady I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Is't ſua? thaun hear ye me Sir; I bid ye hea au care err thaun, he haud need o au laung Spoon thaut ſups we the Deel, I waurren her au aul cheat now before I ſee her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why ſo Willie?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I kent au Maun o my Kintrey thaut mairied au aul wuther'd Wife thaut ſcantly cou'd tell whilk was the Stool and whilk her Arſe whun ſhe ſaut upon't, aun ſometimes ſcaurted her Head inſtead o her Rump; the mairiagemauker ſwear't ſhe was worth ſaux thouſaun pund ſtaurling, aun whun the Gentleman caum tea,—how muckle d'ye think waus o't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Two thouſand pounds it may be.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Twa thouſaun pund! wa be my ſaul ſhoe had na twa hunder Scots Marks, yer Englis Womaun will truſt her perſon whaur ſhe wonna truſt her purſe; ſhe may be a rich Hereiſs tea day, and deel a twa pennys hea the morn gin ye ſoud chance tea tauke her in between yer ſheets.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Away fool, ſome blockhead has inſo m'd the—Madam, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly Sir I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Counſcience I waurran her au honourable pick-pocket, for I dinna like thaut mumping face o hers.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well Sir, I profeſs your buſineſs has coſt me a great deal of trouble; I've been thrice at her Lodgings, and gave a Guinea to her Maid: In a word, Sir, I've ſmooth'd the way, and to morrow you may begin an eaſy Journey to the Iſland of Love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul he haus na, a pair o Boots to ride in.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I'm perſwaded your Addreſſes won't be unwelcom, for I have given you a Character nothing inferior to your merit, and done every thing with that fervour, as if my good or bad fortune had been inſeparably linkt to yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The deel be fain o yer auld wheedling Snout.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, I'm ſenſible of your kindneſs; and thus I expreſs my ſelf. Time, and future events, ſhall inſtruct me how much I'm your Debtor, and how to pay.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Haurk ye Sir, a word we ye in yer lug—keep yer Siller, I kent the Captain cheated out o au hunder Guineas by ſick anither aul wutch aus this.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Whiſper ſoftly ſirrah, otherwiſe ye ruin all.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir—in our Kintry we never buy au meer till eans we ride upon her; pay Sir, I ſay, whun ye get the Lady aun be hang'd till her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sirrah—well, Madam, and when ſhall I have the happineſs of waiting upon the fair Lady?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe expects you to morrow, I'll be there my ſelf in the forenoon, and 'tis convenient you ſhou'd come then—But, Sir, as I hinted to you at our firſt meeting, Fortu • e has been very unjuſt to me, and I'm weary of this trade of life; 'tis but reaſonable then in ſerving others, I ſhou'd ſerve my ſelf, and better my preſent circumſtances in minding yours; the Lady has Ten thouſand pounds, and I demand your Bond only for One; Truly I was never Covetous, and ſuch a Service merits a greater reward, but the c • nfidence I have in your generoſity has taught me to uſe you kindly.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, if I marry the Lady.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, it ſhall be payable upon no other terms.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To morrow you ſhall have it, in the mean time, Madam, believe me your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun the muckle deel thaunk ye, for yer well pay'd for yer pains; hark ye aul woman, I hope me Maiſters ſiller ſall burn the arſe out o yer purſe before night, an be me ſaul aun ye pit au trick upon him this bred Sword ſall let the Sun and Moon ſhine through ye like a glaſs-window.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Devil take the Rogue, he has almoſt frighted me out of my five Senſes—but hitherto all is well, pray heaven that impudent Sot were out of the way, if he has any influence upon his Maſter, my plot on that ſide is ruin'd.

q.l: Miſchief from ſmall beginnings often flows,
But to a Mountain in a minute grows.

div.head: SCENE III.
Lincolns-Inn-Walks.
div.stage: Enter Sir John Winmore and Timandra.
[Capt. Bellair and Flora croſſing the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I Won't, Madam, offer to meaſure the Extent of your power, or ſay I merit; but I'd have you remember, that the World cannot think it ſtrange, that an unnatural parent weakens the bond of obedience, or that a violent paſſion ſhou'd be regarded.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Love it ſeems is a ſtrange paſſion, that of a Lay-man makes an Eccleſiaſtick, and gives you a power to abſolve me from that allegiance I owe to my Uncle and my Guardian—you'd have me come to Confeſſion too, and ſay I lov'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: If you did, I'd prove a kind Ghoſtly father, Madam, and enjoin more of the ſame Sin for a penance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
Sir Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And you'd have me a Companion in miſery.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: No, Madam; for as in Love there are ſome pains, ſo there are pleaſures to ballance them; one kind look from the miſtreſs of our Vows, gives a Joy not to be equall'd; and to be belov'd is a heav'n beyond what dull Philoſophers ever dreamt of.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And if ſhe prove inconſtant?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis Hell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then why ſhou'd I run the hazard of a Love-damnation? Men, what e're they brag, are fickle as the Winds; juſt now they love, and in a moment hate; yet know not whence nor how this Change arrives, but lay the ſtreſs on Fate or Nature's weakneſs: Now if my eaſy heart ſhou'd doat on ſuch a man, I've fool'd my ſelf out of a preſent happineſs, and miſs'd the better heaven I aim'd at.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Your Charms. Madam, ſecure you from that misfortune; your Eyes wou'd melt the heart of a Savage, and turn his fury into love; no man cou'd ever love you leſs; for he who once knew you, wou'd with Joy continue your Slave; your words wou'd call back his wandering thoughts, and fix his nodding vertue to its center.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: —peeping—Uds ſo, here's fine work, my Miſtreſs, by Ovid!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, if you pleaſe, we'll take a turn in the other Walk; Sir Anthony's Son, I find, has dogg'd me hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Every Walk is pleaſant when Timandra's there.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ariſtotle I'll place my ſelf behind this Tree, and obſerve all— Mum, honeſt Dick, here comes another.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Hang me If I'm not ſick with theſe canting words; Flame, Love, Paſſion, Eyes, and the like, I always thought a Soldier ſhou'd be maſter of more Courage than to languiſh for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who wou'd not ſigh when ſo much beauty's nigh? Tantalus ne'er knew pains like mine; for I view a bliſs infinitely beyond his, and find no cauſe, no hope for quick relief.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me believe all you've ſaid, and credit every ſtory for a truth, without remembring your Complements are the effects of your good breeding? You love to ſhow your parts, and that in time of peace; you can remove the thoughts of War's loud alarms, and play with that ſoft young thing call'd Love: Men are ſubject to more changes than Proteus ere knew ſhapes.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid that's very fine. Sir-father, when he knows all will have a truſty houſe-keeper of ye.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who cou'd feign a pleaſure on the Rack, or think of Joys when roaring Seas gap'd wide, and threatn'd preſent ruin; much leſs cou'd I counterfeit a paſſion, or look and not love; to be inſenſible of ſo many Charms, wou'd argue ſtupidity; and to yield without terms to ſo ſweet a Conqueror, ſpeaks not want of Courage, but a generous Confidence.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, the man is damnably in love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, now Captain you begin to be ſerious upon the matter, on my Conſcience I cou'd afford my Pity.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Hercules, the Baggage begins to yield.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pity, Madam, has often prov'd the Mother of Love; if you afford me that, you advance me one ſtep to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Poor man! by Apollo I pity him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, Captain; you'd march before Orders are given; 'tis pit y meerly for your weakneſs: but come, hang this dull ſerious Love, I hate it; let's change the ſubject; I ſee Timandra in the other Walk, who doubtleſs deſires my Company, if attacqu'd as I am.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo? So, ſhe hates dull love; 'tis a ſmart plaguy Wench, all Mercury by Jupiter—but mum, Dick.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You know not, Madam, how far this Love-Caprice may hurry the Old man; your Father's humour is unaccountable, and every thing tends to my ſpeedy ruin, if Melintha prove unkind.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Pan this is my Siſter too; and this is the Rogue that kickt me before my Miſtreſs; I begin to ſhake for fear; if he ſhou'd catch me, he'd ſerve me ſo again: I'll home and tell Sir-father all; by Juno I will.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Remember, Madam, Fortune do's not afford me the happineſs every day of expreſſing all my fears, and your danger.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To a Soul prepar'd no accident is of conſequence; ill fortune comes with downy wings, flies gently by, and leaves no marks of ſorrow in her flight.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I have not yet, Madam, attain'd to that height in Philoſophy; and Love tells me, That without you I am for ever miſerable.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Bellair, Timandra, and Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſhall I wiſh you Joy of your good ſucceſs? but I'm afraid my Siſter is for the Uncle; ſhe can digeſt (it may be) his infirmities for the ſake of thoſe conveniencies his money brings.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'm afraid, M • dam, you've got ſuch another Lover that has poſſeſt the paſſes of your heart, and bars admittance to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A Warlike ſmile, Captain: But I begin to remember we came to hear prayers, and 'tis now paſt time: beſides, I ſaw my Brother juſt now going out of the Garden, who will undoubtedly acquaint my Father with our devotion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Wou'd you begin our Baniſhment ſo ſoon? 'tis but a minute ſince we began to be happy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Neceſſity commands a Ceſſation of Arms; and, Captain, you muſt be broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Yet ſtay, fair Ladies, let theſe cool Shades perſuade, if Lovers fail.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis fitting we change the Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, let us hope you inflict a preſent puniſhment to give a future eaſe; you're afraid too much of Joy ſhou'd ſicken the Soul, and a long Scene of happineſs pale the Appetite: Pain gives a certain reliſh unto Eaſe, and makes it always welcom to the mind.

q.l: Ned. Short Pleaſures moſt of ſolid Joy impart;
And ſtole with hazard, moſt affect the heart.
Nature, to what's forbid, is ſtill inclin'd;
And hopes of Sweets not known, miſ-lead the mind.
Thus we run on, and eagerly purſue
What brings deſtruction, ſo it ſhews but New.
In Love there's no ſuch Curſe, give all to day;
We ſtill Love on, our Joys know no decay,
And every hour to Pleaſure ſhows the way.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
Lucy's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: YOur Fears, Madam, are groundleſs; he's already poſſeſt with an opinion of your Fortune; naturally credulous, and every way fitted for the Cheat; diſſemble handſomly; ſeem not overpliant, yet give him ſtore of hopes, becauſe 'tis neceſſary you ſhou'd be ſpeedily married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſtill doubt the ſucceſs; Fifteen hundred a year is a noble prize; nor are ſuch bubbles often to be found.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: You are ſure he has ſo much, Madam.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Child, very ſure, I know moſt of his Friends and Relations. One thing I had almoſt forgot; if his Servant ſhou'd be rude, take no notice on't; the fellow will rather ſpeak nonſenſe than be ſilent; and I ſuppoſe his Maſter only keeps him for his diverſion.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: E • gad, that Character has almoſt made me in love with him; I admire a talkative gabling fellow; 'tis a ſign of wit, and only ſpeaks his Judgment not yet ripe enough to bound it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I hope you've conſider'd the nature of this Service: Heaven forgive me, I'm forc'd to make many a ſweet Lye for you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My gratitude prompts my memory; accept, Madam, of this ſmall Compliment, and believe me a friend not ſo able as willing to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I always had a good opinion of you, and am glad to find I have not deceiv'd my ſelf—you remember the Bond of a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and own my ſelf oblig'd to pay a greater Sum.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O, dear Madam, I'm o'rewhelm'd with your Bounty; wou'd to heav'n it were in my power to prefer you to a greater Fortune; your Soul ſpeaks you made for great things—I've ſcrew'd her finely up if he has any Eſtate: theſe two thouſand pounds are good; if not, I'm in nothing poorer than I was—Well, Madam, ſhall I admit the Gentleman? he waits in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I ſwear, Madam, you look charmingly to day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ought to pipe with art; for if the fool can be whiſtl'd into the Net, I get a weighty draught—but ſtay, he comes.

div.stage: Re-enter Decoy, with Freelove and Willie.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Swear you have often ſeen her; and, above all, urge her to a ſpeedy marriage; delays are dangerous; and ſhe's courted at this very time by a Rich Knight and two young Citizens of great Credit—Madam, this Worthy Gentleman, a friend of mine, has long ador'd you in ſecret, and my happy Stars having made me of your acquaintance; I'm bold to introduce him into the Temple, where he may worſhip his Goddeſs openly, and receive a reward ſuitable to his Zeal.

sp.speaker: Luc.
Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul the Woman ſpeaks very bonnily.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: My ambition ne'er taught me to aſpi • e to a happineſs beyond Lucinda's favour: I've long lov'd, but had not the liberty of Complaint allow'd me; and now I've got it, methinks I cou'd ſpend an age at her ſeet, and here for ever fix my ſelf; gaze on that fatal beauty that has ſo long baniſh'd peace from my Soul, and almoſt • orc'd me to deſpair.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray Sir riſe.

sp.speaker: D • .
sp.p: That's well; the young Gentleman plays his part to my wiſh; there's a pleaſure in diſſimulation, not to be chang'd for that dull peace of mind which honeſty and plain-dealing beſtow upon their bewitcht Votaries.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is not the firſt time I preſume you've kneel'd: Love e're now has been your Religion, and practice more than innate Zeal has taught you how to pray with ſo much eaſe.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad I believe the Laſs is a Saint.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, Madam, falſe fires can't be of uſe; and if I ſhou'd attempt to act the hypocrite, your Eyes wou'd teach me how to bow.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Deel be fain o me gin thea Englis Women wou'd not mauk au maun's mouth water at them, aun Go • d ſin me new Maiſter is come au Sweethearting tea the Lady; I think Willie ſoud wooe her Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And cou'd you become a Convert? Renounce thoſe principles which allow'd you ſo much liberty, and confine your ſelf to the preciſe rules of marriage.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon— [Whiſpers Lucy. Remember, Madam, he may by accident come to a true knowledge of your circumſtances; when he begins to bite, draw with courage to ſecure him on the hook, for I know he'll leap at the gilded bait, when firſt it offers it ſelf—Adieu ſweet Sir—Pray, Madam, be kind to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The deel ride up throw her aun down throw her, aun a haw-thornbuſs at his tail, aun thaun ſhe needs nea Phyſick.—Goad I can niver endure thea aulwives they look ſua like wutches, aun ſhe waur i my Kintrey ſhe waud be burnt in a taurbaurrel preſently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wou'd I renounce ſuch principles, Madam? by heav'n all the pleaſures of my life, whate're I doated upon; and if a darling Sin were riveted in my heart, with Joy I'd tear the loathſom thing from thence; daſh it from me, and abandon all for the bleſſing of your Love, that wou'd give a happineſs, and in it ſelf contain more bliſs than all the beggar'd earth cou'd give beſides.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hear ye me, Jo: how waud ye like me for yer good man? I hea a brau Eſtate in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Like you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, that is, lye we me au yer days; warm me bed in au caul Winterneight, aun let me get bairns upon ye.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Is that your way of Courtſhip in Scotland?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, aun this way tea be me Saul—we gang red wood upon bonny Laſſes. 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns thauts the way of your Englis Women, ſhe is ready to cry out, whun ony body is near, haun her baut gin ſhe waur at the bauck of au dike whaur deel au ean ſees her, ſhe waud be aus caum as au laum, and let a laud kiſs his weam fou.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But pray thee ſpeak Engliſh, elſe 'tis impoſſible to comprehend thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun I had ye au mile frea au houſe ye waud underſtaun me meaning for au thaut.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cou'd you ſit, and with a calm brow obſerve the dear Companions of your paſt liberty roving after new Loves? wou'd you not flutter in your Cage and wiſh for freedom; envy thoſe who rang'd through open air, and curſe the hour that fool'd you into priſon?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'd view ſecurely men in Tempeſts toſt, pity the weary and miſguided Travellers; and when I ſaw them tracing Danger's road, in ſearch of Joys that vaniſh as ſoon as got, I'd ſhrink up in ſilent gladneſs, and bleſs my kinder ſtars that gave me wealth and happineſs at home; I'd bid them be wiſe, and learn to love from me; run quick for ſafety to ſome conſtant Fair, whoſe charms give eaſe from all their labours paſt.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now deel tauke me gin me Maſter does na wooe aus bonnily aus I waud do me ſell, only he forgets tea kiſs her—Hear ye, Sir, tauke her in yer arms this way, aun be me ſaul ſhoe wull grow ſua tame, ye may lead her tea the Kirk in au ſtring, ſhe wull gaung wood toe be mairied upon ye.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sirrah—Madam, I hope you'll pardon this rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love to ſee the fellow in that antick garb; it puts me in mind of the old World, when Cloaths were uſed for Neceſſity, not Orn • ment.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaun I was in me ain Kintrey, Maudam, the Miniſter's Wife ſaid I waus the bonnieſt Laud in au her good man's pariſh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Did ſhe?—I love the humours of ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Maudam, aun yea hea au mein tea marry me inſteed o me maiſter, be me ſaul I wull tauke ye preſently, I waud na let a bonny Laſs rin wood for waunt o me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This, Madam, is intolerable Impudence—to your diſtance, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay Sir, whaut's the matter we ye now? ye look like a Miniſter whun he has newly loſt his Baunifice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have you got a Miſtreſs, Willie, ſince you came to England?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau, Madam; baut I hea gotten ean here aun ſhe aun I caun agree, we may come tea confirm the bargain between a pair o blankets.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And what wou'd you think of making the bargain there, and confirming on't afterwards? I've a Maidenhead to diſpoſe of, I aſſure ye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Wau thaun we ſall ſave the expences o'Kirk-fees, aun make the bar gaun like our for-bearers; I ſall gang in to ye aun be acquainted we ye and ſu •
forth, we cau thaut only playing a tune without a prelude.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Ay, but Willie, 'tis neceſſary the Church ſhou'd give us liberty to play, elſe we may come to pay too dear for our Muſick.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You ſee, Madam, they have come already to Articles; I can propoſe none, but I've a heart at your ſervice, I give it, ne'er to be recall'd; for tho' your powerful Charms forc'd me to make the gift, yet my conſent ſoon follow'd; my Judgment confirm'd it, and it will ſtand good in law.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm afraid, tho' it were ſeal'd and deliver'd in the Church, you wou'd find ſome corner to ſculk in, and pretend to other terms; ſwear the delivery was conditional, and you gave it with a proſpect of poſſeſſing another to ſupply the want of your own—but however, my modeſty bounds my words, yet I'm willing my Eyes ſhou'd expreſs my thoughts, and let you know your addreſſes are—not—unacceptable.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I've no way left to expreſs my Joy; Silence ſpeaks my Soul o'recharg'd with ſudden happineſs; and he who loves like me, muſt court in dumb ſhow; may all your hours be a continued ſcene of gladneſs, like that which reigns at my heart; and may each minute of your life produce new Joys, that when you have run through all the pleaſures this world can beflow, death may ſteal upon you like a gentle friend, that comes to wa • t you to a better ſhore—but rather than be troubleſome to her I love, I chuſe to inflict a ſhort baniſhment upon my ſelf, tho' I go with all the pains of an abſent Lover—Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun whaut ſay ye tea me before I gaung away?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Why nothing, follow your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Aun my Maſter be in au great haiſt, he may ſtay au we bitt. Aun he aun his Laſs hea made a bargain ſua his nau Wulle too.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come, pray thee be gone, thou art troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be goad aun ye ſall • ee my bauckſide preſently, troubleſome quo; thau't aun Englis Woman's breeding aun he haunget till her— [to Lucy. Madam, fair ye weil, aun ye hea any thing tea ſay tea me, ye wull ſee me whun I come back again.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Well, Madam, our affairs have put on a handſome face to day; Fortune begins to ſmooth her brow, and grace us with her ſmiles—'tis a luſty handſome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The preſent proſpect ſhows a long train of coming Joys; Heav'n begins to ſmile upon me, ſince I abandon'd my old ſin of doating; and if I ſucceed in this innocent cheat, I ſhall ne're tempt its goodneſs more.

q.l: None ere grew vertuous but by juſt degrees,
Nor trac'd the road to happineſs but with eaſe.
Cuſtom a ſecond nature oft has prov'd;
And 'tis with labour and regret we're mov'd,
To quit thoſe darling pleaſures once we lov'd.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Anthony's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony Chollerick and Dick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: HAve a minute's patience; I ſay, Neighbour, all is not loſt that is in hazard, as the ſaying is.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir-father ſays very well; I had a Latin Proverb to the ſame purpoſe, but by Seneca I've forgot it.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well; I've done, I've done; but that impudent young Jilt—but I've done. I'll ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Your Houſe-keeper will ſet all to-rights again; ſhe ſhall guard them to night, and prepare things neceſſary for this great occaſion, that Melintha
may be married like the Daughter of Sir Anthony Addle; your Niece ſhall lye in my houſe too, and the morrow's Sun ſhall ſee an alliance confirm'd between our Families, which nothing leſs than death ſhall diſſolve.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But uds ſo, I forgot to tell you how the Rogue kickt me before my Miſtreſs, and wou'd have done the ſame again in the Walks, had I not been oblig'd to my heels that brought me off unſeen.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: How—O Lord! that Rogue, I profeſs, will make me mad.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Make him mad, Sir father? by Venus he's mad already.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: That was a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, was it not?—a Villain—I knew he wou'd be graceleſs; why ſome months ago I found him in his Cloſet a writing of a Play; well, he's a Rogue, a Dog, a Scoundrel, a Rake, and will dye a Beggar—but no more on't; only I'm ſure my Brother Sir Thomas Chollerick ne'er begot this limb of Satan.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: But as I was ſaying, that was a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, that's certain, he'll ne'er eſcape the Gallows; I've known that young—I'll ſay no more—I profeſs I've known the Rake come home at night with as many Filders, Hautboys, Starving Poets, and red-fac'd Bullies—Why the Raſcal has come home with as many empty bellies at his back, as his Majeſty's Huntſmen with all his Dogs after him; and then a Surloin of Beef, or a Cold pye—why 'twas no more amongſt them than a pennyworth of Cheeſe to a luſty Porter; but I'll make him a—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely ſpeaking, I begin to ſhow my weakneſs, my blood will riſe, and I ſay your Nephew—

sp.speaker: Choll.
Dick.
sp.p: No, no; but by Bacchus—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, the Rogue wou'd provoke a Saint to wrath; but I'll be reveng'd, I will; he ſhan't o're-rule me, a—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I ſay your Nephew ſhall be puniſh'd by Law; ſuch affronts as theſe derogate from the honour of my houſe; and 'tis fitting a—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: And had the Impudence to ſerve him ſo beneath my roof: but no more on't, the Knave ſhall pay dear for all.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely ſpeaking, Neighbour Chollerick. I think you are a Madman, and I ought to have the liberty of Speech allow'd me in my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, and in your own Cauſe too.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Cauſe, as the Young man ſays? why look ye now, the Rogue has given me cauſe to turn him looſe into the World, and I'll do' • I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ingenuouſly I'm incens'd, I can hold no longer; I ſay, Neighbour, hear me, or turn out of my • houſe; I'm reſolv'd to be maſter of my own family.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: You ſay right, I've done, I've done.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well then, I ſay, a Juſtice of the Peace ſhall take Cognizance of this affair—but here comes your Houſe • keeper.

div.p: Madam, having taken—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Why look ye, d'ye ſee, we have ſent for you to—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the man will never let me ſpeak—having, Madam, taken—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, ſay on Sir-father.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Why ſincerely I ſhall never begin at this rate; having, Madam, taken into our Conſideration the extravagant inclinations of our Children, and thoſe who reſpectively depend on us, and maturely conſider'd the ſad Conſequences that may attend ſuch courſes; and that ſome who have never ſhown themſelves affectionate to our Government, ſignaliz'd themſelves yeſterday in ſeducing the hearts of our Daughters: It is the will and pleaſure therefore of your Maſter, that by vertue of the authority now given and repos'd in you.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father ſpeaks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: For the future prevent all ſuch unlawful courſes and methods, that no Correſpondence may be held between them hereafter; for we are firmly reſolv'd by ſtratagems and new politicks to keep theſe cunning Gentlemen from the poſſeſſion of theſe Lands to which they aſpire.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, that was a thund'ring Speech; ſure the Rogues will never have the Impudence to make any more addreſſes—my Siſters will never accept of them.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye d'ye ſee, without further ceremony ſtay here all night, and look to the young women; my Neice is already here, and to morrow ſhall be married; in the mean time 'tis fitting we ſhou'd provide Counſel; but let that be your task; and mine, to procure Licenſe.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid here's fine work, we ſhall all go over head and ears in Matrimony.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I'll obey your Orders punctually; and to ſave you the expences of Coach-hire, I know of a Lawyer, who will wait upon you when call'd, and do the buſineſs for a Glaſs of Wine, without the help of a Fee to ſweeten it: I'm acquainted too with a Nonconformiſt Parſon, who has a wonderful dexterity in joining hands and hearts.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's good, that's good; be ſure you ſpeak to them.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well, Neighbour, let's go, every thing ſhall be in readineſs; I'll have a new Suit too, that I may grace the Nuptials with my gaiety; they ſhall go no more to the Walks.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: In ſtatu quo prius you mean Sir-father; for if I live, they ſhan't all carry their Maidenheads with them; if they do—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, the boy grows wanton—but 'tis no matter, a month or ſo will tame him; I was young my ſelf, and can remember theſe things ſtill—Dick come along Dick.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Good b'ye, I'll ſee you again in an hours time.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: So this has happen'd to my wiſh now the Ladies are committed to my charge; and ſince 'tis mine to provide Counſel, 'tis in my power to advance all their Joys: let me dye 'tis a ſweet adventure, and I'm reſolv'd to build my fortune ſo ſtrongly (for that will make them liberal) upon the neceſſities of the young people, that the frowns of the old can never ſhake me; 'tis a good foundation, ay, and here come materials fit for the Structure.

div.p: Oh, Ladies! here have been ſtrange doings; Sir Anthony and Mr. Chollerick are acquainted with all that paſs'd yeſternight in Lincolns-Inn; the young Philoſopher has play'd the Conjurer, and infor'd your enemies of all your deſigns.

sp.speaker: Mel
sp.p: No, he turn'd ſpy it ſeems, but the old man will ſoon forget it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Ay, but Madam, you're condemn'd, and you too Madam; to morrow's markt out for Execution-day, and I'm your Jaylor by ſpecial orders from the higher powers—there's no way left to eſcape.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I'm in priſon, but not condemn'd I hope.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And pray thee, Decoy, wilt thou not admit of Bail.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O dear Madam, by no means, in caſes of High-treaſon there's no ſuch thing after Judgment given.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sure thou haſt not ſo much of cruelty in thy Nature; to wink at ſmall faults, ſpeaks thee tender-hearted; a quality inherent to woman.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Self-preſervation bars the thoughts of mercy; and if the Priſoners eſcape, the Keeper may ſhift for himſelf, or ſtay for certain puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm ſorry my Judgment and Experience did not ſooner inform me of my Error—What d'ye think of this, Madam? I hope 'twill buy off my Chains, if it do not purchaſe Freedom.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, your generoſity ſtaggers my ſtrongeſt reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Her zeal for my Father's arbitrary Government begins to cool, Siſter; ply her with ſuch another argument as mine, and ſhe'll throw off all Obedience, and become a rebel like our ſelves, and fly (tho' not directly) in the face of all Authority.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: If this can tempt her, She's of our party.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And this ſhall help to confirm the Convert in her new tenets, that obedience is an effect of Intereſt, and 'tis madneſs to continue allegiance when that tye is broke, or better ſecur'd with the Enemy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: As I live, fair Ladies, you've o'recome me, you've Juſtice on your ſide; 'tis impoſſible to raiſe any objections againſt ſuch powerful arguments—Who's this?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be my Saul this is the aul Jaude thaut mumped me new Maiſter out o his Siller—Maudaum, I hea brought ye an Letter frea Sir John—me bonny Laſſes how d'ye do, yer Sweethearts aur ſtauning ſighing in the cauſy, aun look like ſua mony clipped ſheep; a goad I believe they wull gang dauft for want o ye.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Run Ladies into the other room, I'm but Deputy-Governeſs, and 'tis not ſafe to meet with your Lovers, unleſs I were aſſured of my Superior's continued abſence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well, Madam, remember the weight of our paſt arguments, and let no new accident divert your reſolution.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Tell the Gentlemen their humble Servant Decoy waits to receive them with all humility.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, baut ye ſoud nea hea ſent awau the women thaun, for be me ſaul they wunnau gaung out o the houſe till the be as ſure o them aus me faither was o me mither that night Wulle was begotten upon her.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Now for another Caſt of my Art; for that Match-maker knows not her own trade, who fails at any time to make them pay for their hopes; if we are not courted with as many Guineas as their Miſtreſſes with Oaths, we manage amiſs, and loſe our own fortunes, becauſe we have too much of modeſty—Gentlement, I'm your humble Servant.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, Captain, Ned, and Willie.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you know our buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun thaut ſhe does, for I tellt her o't.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I know too much; for my want of power to ſerve you in this affair brings my grief.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You jeſt, Madam; ſure 'tis impoſſible you ſhou'd be inſenſible of our Common Calamity.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir! I'm a ſharer in all your Fortunes, and wou'd relieve you from pain with all my heart; but—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: You'd run no hazard to ſerve your friends—Damn her, ſhe muſt be brib'd, ſhe's like a new Coach-wheel, often greas'd before ſhe can run ſmooth.

sp.speaker: Sir. Jo.
sp.p: Can't this perſuade?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Madam, accept of this ſmall Complement.

sp.speaker: N • d.
sp.p: And I humbly offer theſe few Yellow-boys to procure your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wa Sirs, wa Sirs: are ye reed wood tea gea awau yer ſiller—wa goad the Laſſes aur na ſaunted, ye may get them for the half of this trouble.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I proteſt ſincerely, Gentlemen, I know not what to ſay t'ye—but in ſpite of danger, you ſhall once more be happy by my means—I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By our Money he wou'd have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns cau ye this wooing Alamode! this is an Englis trick indeed, a maun mun gee ſiller for an ſight o his Sweetheart, aus we do in Scotlaun tea ſee au dancing Meer, or au Eape playing on the Bagpipes.

div.stage: [Goes off. [The flat Scene opens, and diſcovers Sir John, Captain, Ned, Willie, Timandra, Melintha, Flora, and Decoy: The Captain and Flora advance, and Wilie after them.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All danger ought to be deſpis'd when Love has any ſhare in the action; the prize before us ſhould give Courage, and ſpur us on to Victory.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why you're at your old ſimilies again, Captain, action, prize, and victory; ſure you imagine to your ſelf a formal ſiege when you attack a Lady; I hope you don't muſter your Company in the Tavern, and • et the Bottles in battle-array inſtead of men.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me S • ul he threw • an o thea men at my head hauf au yeir ſeen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I confeſs, Madam, a Lady is a ſtrange Enemy; for a Soldier finds it often more difficult to get acceſs to her Soul, than to throw in proviſions to a Town beſieg'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad my Maiſter aunt like your Ladiſhip wull ſtorm a Fort we ony laud in au Lonon aun ye wull gee him a Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah—ha, who's this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Thieves! Thieves! Thieves!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Farewel, Captain; remember, a Town once loſt has been regain'd.

div.stage: [Flora goes off, and the other Ladies in haſte.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How, Sir!—draws—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Murder! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O Lord, I'am murder'd auready; whaut a deel brought me in tea this unlucky houſe aun 〈◊〉 ſua now?

div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony and Sevant • with long Staffs, and Dick with his Sword drawn behind them, and walking backwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, I ſay, ſecure the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, knock 'em down; by Jupiter we ſhall all be murder'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me ſaul I'm a dead man; I wull hide me ſell beneath this Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Come, let's force a p • ſſage to our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.stage: [They fight, and the Servants give way on each ſide.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Choll. Ned, Ned,
sp.p: Good boy, thou won't murder thy Uncle—O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I'm dead.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Vulcan ſo am I—knock 'em down, I ſay knock 'em down; Sirfather ſhall keep ye all from harm.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Knock 'em down—why look ye now d'ye ſee, they are all gone. Ah that Rogue my Nephew ſhall be hang'd—a dog, a—

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo Sir-father, I ſcowr'd 'em off, Rogues, Pimps, Panders, and Scoundrels; by Ariſtotle I've frighted them; this Sword did execution; but I'll put it up, becauſe my Uncle that is to be, is here.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul I waud I waur i' me ain Kintrey again, Englaun ſoud niver hea the honour o'me preſence aun they waud mauke a King o'me.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I faint, help me forwards; I'll lean upon this Table, and recover breath.

div.stage: [As he goes to reſt upon it, Dick o'returns it.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, d'ye ſee; whow have we got here? another Rogue! the houſe is full of them, wou'd I were fairly out on't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Gaung awau thaun, whau au deel hauds, au grip o'ye—agoad I believe me Maiſter has left me here to be hangett.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, let me alone with him; this is Sinon that was to open the wooden-horſe, and let out all the Grecians.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul the Englis-men will hea na mercy on me, I fin thaut; baut aun I cou'd get ſafe to the door, they ſoud na ou lay ſaut I me arſe the night again.

div.stage: [Offers to run, and Dick ſtops him.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Uds ſo, not ſo faſt, you ſhall leave your head behind ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the boy Dick is bloodily diſpos'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be goad ſein na better may be, I wull fight for my head furſt—I'll gaur ye au loap like Dinmonts—I wull let ye ken whaut it is tea anger a Scotlaun maun.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: O Lord! O Lord! I'm murder'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And ſo are all of us.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The muckle deel mauke oare ye waud na be at reſt till I dous'd yer doublets for ye; baut now I hea learnt ye mainers we this bred Sword, I'll gang and ſeek my new Maiſter.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, this was a damn'd bloody Dog.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, I ſee no heads he has left behind him but our three Calves-heads.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No matter, 'tis a mercy he has left thoſe: but where's Madam Decoy, Body o'me? Alderman Chollerick, I ſay your Houſe-keeper is naught, and has betray'd her Truſt.

div.stage: Enter Decoy in a ſeeming amazement.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, here ſhe is; look ye now, look ye now, you was brought
here to a fine purpoſe; you was, a very fine purpoſe; but 'tis no matter—I'll be reveng'd one day or other.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Heav'n knows Sir I knew nothing of the matter till juſt now I met the lewd fellows in the ſtreets: I was at Mr. Delay the Lawyer, and Mr. Sigher's the Nonconformiſt—God knows I did it purely for the beſt, and ſtole out on foot to ſave expences.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely ſpeaking, I believe the Woman is innocent.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Mercury I believe ſo too.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: I've done then, Madam: look ye, look ye to your charge: Farewel, for I've not yet diſpatch'd the buſineſs of this day.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come along, Dick; come along.

q.l: The fighting Fool gets Scars; but he that's wiſe
Preſerves his Skin, and from known Danger flies:
Honour's an empty Sound, admir'd by thoſe
Who have no Brains, or no Eſtate to loſe.
While thoſe by Fortune bleſt, look-wiſely on,
And ſee this airy Miſtreſs loſt or won;
But without Danger to be got by none.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: WIth difficulty I've got out of doors, but the old Lover and the young have reliev'd me from my poſt; my three principal Lovers are uneaſy on both ſides, and from the Gentlemen I've receiv'd fifty Guineas this morning to compleat their cure; nor have I forgot to ſqueeze the young Ladies, even to their very Jewels; I can expect no more than I've already got by both parties; for ſhou'd I now baulk them in this Intrigue, they'd never truſt me again: I've worn them almoſt threadbare, and 'tis time to lay them aſide; I'll give therefore the finiſhing ſtroke to this plot, hitherto ſo well manag'd, and ſhow my ſelf honeſt, becauſe I can find no profit by a longer delay. As for Mr. Freelove's marriage with Lucy, 'tis eaſy, their mutual fears will force them to a ſpeedy obedience, and I'll enjoin an immediate conjunction between them. Mum, here he comes; I'm glad I have his Bond and hers; 'tis a large Fee for a She-Counſel—Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I've punctually obey'd thoſe Orders you ſent me this morning; every thing is in readineſs, and I wiſh the young Lady may—

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, doubt it not, I've div'd into her inmoſt thoughts; but the buſineſs muſt be ſpeedily diſpatch'd, for her friends begin to pry into't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Begoad Sir I wull feght we au her freins, and gar 'em gee conſeut, wa I clawed off three Englis-men yeſterday.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon, the Lady enters—Madam, for your own ſake embrace this opportunity which now offers it ſelf; his friends are advertis'd of his deſign, and ſtudy to break off the Match—Now I've brought ye once more together, I know ye both love, and it were a ſin to part ye, 'tis hard to pleaſe every body, and I'd have you join for ever, leſt you meet no more.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay do ſua my bairns, agoad I wull daunce at yer breidall.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, yeſterday you taught me to hope; to day brings new alarms, and an hours delay may bring me years of pain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wuns I ſay tauke him, tauke him, Madam, he will ſet yer Watermill au gaunging.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, conſider the Gentleman's violent Love, that he hunts not for a Fortune; and that he prefers your Eſteem to his Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Haud yer chau • ts togither in au miſchanter t'ye, aun let the Lauſs aunſwer for her ſell; agoad I waurran, ſhe knes whaut's good for her.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Do, Madam; pity the Gentleman; I'll ſwear 'tis a ſhame to be ſo hard hearted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Be me Saul thea women hea na mair power cur their tongues than they hea our their tails, aun thauts no muckle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I own I'm powerfully aſſaulted, and modeſty only detains me from ſaying I—Love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now be me Saul ſhe ſays very weill.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Then thus I render thanks for the mighty bleſſing; my heart ſcorns its narrow bounds, and ſeeks for greater Joys than e're it knew—let me kiſs this fair hand, and in that (not words) expreſs my tranſports.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hout, hout, Sir, kiſs her bonny mouth, whaut a deel wull ſhe be the better o' yer kindneſs aun ye do na mair nor thaut till her.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: 'Tis rarely acted, they are at no ſmall pains to che • t one another; and both of them diſſemble with as much pleaſure, as a luſty Frier wou'd eat a fat Capon after a tedious Lent—Well, Madam, a thouſand bleſſings attend you; believe me, I cou'd weep for gladneſs to ſee you thus far on the way to a happi •• r ſtate of life—Compleat the Gentleman's Joys, for 'tis a Sin that two ſuch loving hearts ſhould be ſo long divided.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Speak, Madam, ſpeak; he that like me is bleſt only by halves in that uncertain ſtate, finds certain pains; the preſent pleaſure's loſt in hopes of more, and fears of future events rack the Soul.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sure Mad • m your heart yields.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.p: Come, Madam, lay aſide that confounded modeſty invented by old decay'd Beauties to torment the young and bar 'em of thoſe pleaſures of which their envious age permitted them not to be ſharers—the Gentleman's addreſſes are very honourable.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, tauke her ſilence for a grant, come awau tea the K •• k we her, ſhe wull gaung we good wull I'ſe waurran her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I can be no longer obſtinate, I'll yield a blind obedience, and • ye my ſelf for ever Freeloves.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Goad aun fair fau her for her kindneſs aun en ſua.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, now my Joys are no more to be expreſt.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nau deel be fain o' me gin our lairds Siſter whir I waus born in Scotlaun waud ſaid ſua mickle tea au young maun aun ſhe ſoud never be maired in her days. Baut a goad for au that ſhe can play in the dark we young meaſt Chaplain, au caunting young loun as is in au the kirk again.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I can hold no longer, exceſs of Joy brings forth my tears: pray heav'ns bleſs you, you are a lovely couple as ever I put together in my life.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Whaut au deel ails the auld wife now, kens ony body that?

sp.speaker: Dec.
Luc.
sp.p: I'll obey, Madam—I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Run laus will ye rin aun get the Miniſter tea mairy me Maiſter, aun get anither to mairy me.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Well, well; Willie, I'll think upon't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Do ſua me Jo—now Iſe gaung in, aun wait upon me maiſter, whau kens baut I may get the leg of a Capon tea me wauden dinner, ſhame fa me gin I hea-na mickle need o't, for I fin a civil war i me guts▪ aun my puddings are gaunging tea eat an aunother.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Anthony's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir Anthony, Dick and Chollerick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: So boy, look brisk, body o' me, 'tis a handſome Lad.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, I'll make ye a Grand-father in nine Months.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye, friend, that part is mine, I was born before you, was I not?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter I hope ye wou'd not lye with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's right, that's right, I invited ſome of my Friends to be merry with us to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And I have invited Mr. Caperer the Dancing maſter, and Chorus the Muſick-maſter, the poor Rogues owe me ſome money, and I'm reſolv'd they ſhall dance and ſing it out this night; charges upon ſuch occaſions are inevitable—have you invited your Nephew?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: A Rogue, a Villain, I'll ſee him hang firſt; invite him! why look ye now, d'ye ſee;—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I ſay, Neighbour, abandon your wrath, let not your paſſion baniſh Reaſon, I am not deſirous of the young man's Company.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's true, that's true, I forget my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, I think you have always a damnable memory.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Call my Daughters and Mr. Chollerick's Niece, are the Lawyers come? is the Parſon ready, and every thing in order?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir I've forgot nothing.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Call them in.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, you might have put on a new ſuit, Uncle; that is, to be for a new wiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o' me, that's true, 'tis an undecent garb for a Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's nothing: look ye, I love my money, and therefore wou'd not disburſe it for trifles; I'll give my Wife a Complement of five hundred broad-pieces in an imbroidred purſe; your vain Coxcombs, who ſpend all on Plays, Paints, Perſumes, and long Wiggs, have no ſuch gifts to beſtow; they bring a pair of lac'd breeches to the beds-ſide, but not one farthing in 'em.

div.stage: Enter Timand • a, Flora, Melintha and Decoy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Ladies, be of good courage, I've a plot will ſave you all, though on the brink of ruin.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, let me ſee no ſigns of Sorrow in your face, I have provided for you a wealthy husband—Dick, bear up to the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look, d'ye ſee, young woman? look kindly upon him, he's a handſome youth; do't, or expect my immediate diſpleaſure; turn out o' doors, run mad for want, and go to Bedlam at laſt for ſhelter, you ſhall, you—but I'd almoſt forgot my ſelf again, temptation is a dangerous thing, and all men are wiſe till they have occaſion to ſhew their parts.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father I'l ſpeak to her—Madam, you and I are like to be good friends ere to morrow morning; by Jupiter if I had you—I know where I wou'd be.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: At the Univerſity again it may be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: The Univerſity! No, by Ariſtotle I'm for no ſuch Journeys, I'll teach you Natural Philoſophy here in London.—Uds ſo, but Marriage is a damn'd thing, that allows me but one Scholar; my Sir-father (when he was a young man) had forty, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Enter Sir
sp.p: John Winmore, Capt. Bellair, as Lawyers; Ned Chollerick like a Noncon-Parſon, and Decoy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: We are now fairly in, Madam, and upon you we rely for a fairer Exit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I hope the old Gentlemen know us not in our new Shapes.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Leave all to my management, and the event ſhall anſwer your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis he, Mars, appears in Maſquerade, and ſhines throughout muſty black.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you're welcome.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Sir, I've brought two Councellors.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Very well, very well, I can read Noverint univerſi in their foreh • ads at this diſtance—are the Papers ready?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—are you ready, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Before you make a good Council.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Am I happy, Madam? or doom'd to miſery? I am a bad Lawyer when my Eyes muſt plead my Cauſe, and I'm oblig'd without Arguments to refer all to my Judge?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: The adverſe-party have authority on their fide, which may be much to their advantage.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, 'tis a Jolly young Parſon: ſhall—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Preſently boy thou ſhalt be a married man.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p:
By Ovid, Sir-father, I begin to grow proud on't, my head ſtands juſt now as ſtiff as if the marks of honour already preſs'd my brow. M • rriage
is a notable trick, that in a minute, of a raw boy makes a grave ſolid lump of a man.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Is the young Divine, or the old Merchant, the happy Lover? you ſee love has transform'd me into a new man; I run the riſque of Church-cenſure too in pretending to marriages without Orders; but I hope that in this Cloak (the cover of many infirmities) 'twill be eaſy to eſcape the inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yes, if I am Sinner enough to digeſt a hypocrite, and take up with a me • r ſhew of S • nctity and Religion.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman below-ſtairs waits for ye.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Vulcan that's ſome Univerſity-acquaintance or other, I'll bring him up, and ſhew him how happy I am to be in a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, let's ſee the papers—Mr. Sigher, pray ſit down a little, for the Law muſt be ſtill before the Goſpel—what's this? read the Contents.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ay, ay, read the Continents.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: This is, Sir, a Settlement of four hundred per annum upon your eldeſt lawful begotten Son Richard Addle, out of that Eſtate lying in the Country of Nullibi, in—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Pray read it, Sir, word by word.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I'm in haſte, buſineſs calls me ſpeedily hence, and I humbly beg your excuſe, I ſhall warrant it right—pox on the Law, I'm wearied on't already.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Very good; no matter; and what's this large Scroll?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: The honourable Sir Anthony Addle beſtows upon his Daughter eight thouſand Pounds to be paid the firſt of January next enſuing.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: A long term, the firſt of January next enſuing! Why look ye d'ye ſee, the Intereſt of the money at Six per Cent. comes to—ay, let me ſee, comes to—but no matter, January next, why 'tis a whole year to'r.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the Man is in a paſſion before all theſe Witneſſes: I ſay Neighbour Chollerick you love not my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No faith, Sir; but your money ſets his heart on fire.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well, I've done—and what have we got here?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir, contains—

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What Sir? let me ſee what does it contain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now, Madam, quick relief, or we're all undone.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, 'tis a coming.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I'm frighted out of my Senſes, your Son, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ay, Body o'me, that's true; where is the young Man?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, Arreſted, the Bailiffs have got him, 'tis an Action of Ten thouſand pounds: O, Sir, he's almoſt dead with fear, and e're now he's either in the Spunging-houſe, or the Counter.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, look ye now, d'ye ſe • , he has play'd ſome Rogue's trick, and now he's catcht.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: This works rarely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thank ye, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I ſay, Neighbour, you are—but no matter—a Rogue's trick!

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Well, well, I've done; no more on't; let's run and Ba • l him.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: By all means, 'twas well mov'd; ſincerely 'twas an unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Stop 'em, ſtop 'em; now's your time to have the Papers ſubſcrib'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Stay, Gentlemen, ſtay; firſt put your Hands and Seals to theſe Papers; you know we have much buſineſs, and can't wait your return.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: That's right, one thing ſhou'd be done before another: which is mine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Both theſe are yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Now all's done, let's run, Neighbour, for my Son's relief: the delivery of the Papers is forgot; but no matter, we'll do't when we come back.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, play your game well; the Stakes lye ready before ye, and here are no old Bullies to ſweep the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, you ſee the Common danger (for ſuch I hope you'll own it) our good Fortune has allow'd this Critical minute for us all: which, if well imploy'd, brings a continu'd happineſs—we've been good Counſellors too.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Now, Revenge, Love, and Liberty call aloud: ſure ſuch powerful muſick muſt affect the heart, and ſet the ſoul afloat.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, Ceremonies are now dangerous, becauſe tedious; I'm fairly reſolv'd to go with ye.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And I.

div.stage: [They run off, Mel. Tim. Sir John and Ned, Decoy following.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You'll ſtay behind I ſuppoſe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why faith, Captain, I doubt whether I ſhall or not.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you do, Madam, then I muſt ſleep a Batchellor to night.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, hang it, that's a dull comfortleſs life; I'll rather try the Fool's Paradiſe, and for once be married.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's well thought of; the Gentleman in Black, I ſuppoſe, has conjur'd Sir John already half way into the Circle; let us ſucceed, and get the ſecond or third caſt of his Office.

div.stage: Enter Sir Anth. Choll. and Dick.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the Rogues ſhall be ſeverely puniſh'd; why, they had not a Writ againſt the Young-man.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Ovid I'm ſick, the Rogues have frighted me ſo, I ſhan't be able to ſhow my ſelf a man to night again.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Villains, Vagabonds, Rakes, Raſcals, Sons of—G • d forgive me, they had almoſt ſpoil'd our mirth; Rogues—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sincerely 'tis no matter, all's well again: now to our buſineſs—ha! where are the Lawyers?—gone—hoa? who waits there?

div.p: Where are the Law • ers? the Parſon? and my Daughters?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: And my Niece; my Niece I ask?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: All gone abroad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me! we're betray'd, cheated, ruin'd, and undone.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Pox on your Houſe-keepers Lawyers, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: 'Tis rare work, and Ned has a hand in't; that young Dog muſt have a finger in the pye; I'll have him hang'd; I'll have him hang'd, Tyburn is too good for the Rogue—O that Vill •• n!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter I'm finely ſerv'd, I've loſt my Supper, juſt when my Appetite had taught me to long for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Run, Sirrah, run; cry, ſtop the Thieves, the Murderers, the Robbers, the any-things, body o'me, all's loſt.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, Captain Ned, Mel. Flo. and Tim.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis not loſt, that is on a friend beſtow'd.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: So▪ Sirrah; I knew the Rogue was one at this miſchief; I knew't you dog you, I'll make you—let me come at him—this Ca • e and his Shoulders muſt renew their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, we have entertain'd Wolves in Sheeps-cloathing.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: By Jupiter, two of them were in Fox's Cloathing: but uds ſo, I hope they are not married, Sir-father.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Thus low I kneel to beg your Bleſſing: this Gentleman is your Son, and my Husband.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: A damn'd confounded Rogue, is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Body o'me, the young Woman has out-witted me: but ſince ſhe's married to a Knight's Son, I forgive her; I ever eſteem'd your Father Sir Thomas—Riſe, Daughter; prove an obedient Wife, and my Bleſſing ſhall never be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: This ſudden Change ſpeaks the goodneſs of your Nature; nor ſhall my duty (if poſſible) ever ſhow it ſelf leſs than your kindneſs—this Gentleman too deſerves your pardon and eſteem.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How! body o'me! Flo. married!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir, I long'd to taſte the ſweet Sin of Rebellion: and now the fact is committed, I want a Remiſſion.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir father; the Jades are all mad.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Ned, Sirrah, Raſcal, are you really married to this Woman? Durſt you uſe your Unkle thus?—'Twas a needleſs queſtion, the graceleſs Villain wou'd ſtick at nothing; but I'll be reveng'd, I will, Sirrah; let them all ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's paſt can't be recall'd; the Girl was ne'er (it ſeems) ordain'd for a Nun, and the method ſhe has purſu'd perſwades me ſhe has Wit: I wiſh you, Sir, all that happineſs you deſire; may you be envied by none, and eſteem'd by all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This indeed alone cou'd add to my happineſs: your friendſhip and this young Lady's love exalt me above the reach of F • rtune's malice: ſhou'd ſhe now • rown, I'd laugh at her weakneſs; ſhe can give no more, for this mighty gift has exhauſted all her treaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I've preſum'd without your Conſent to marry your Niece, my—

sp.speaker: Choll.
Sir Jo.
sp.p: No, Sir, this ſecures me from that plague you threaten.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: What's that, Sirrah?—I profeſs I long to ſwinge this Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Ten thouſand pounds Alderman Chollerick gave me with his Niece; I ſuppoſe 'twas all her own.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Oh Dog! oh Villain! oh Wretch! I'm chous'd! ruin'd! and—but 'tis no matter! I'll be reveng'd; I'll have Law; I'll ſpend all I have in the recovery of my right, I will—let me come at him—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Have patience, Neighbour, body o' me, I begin to think that I'm no better us'd than I ſhou'd be.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, I've made bold with eight thouſand pounds inſtead of that deſign'd for your Son.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And body o' me, I ſuppoſe you've been ſuch another Counſellor.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, faith, Sir, I preſume ye know theſe Letters to be of your own making.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sinceely ſpeaking, 'tis ſo; I hope however I've got diſcrcet Creditors who won't ſue a Commiſſion of Bankrupt againſt me.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye Ned; you're a Rogue, a confounded unlucky Villain.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, ſo he is, and us'd me once very Scurvily; but by Iupiter I dare not complain, leſt he renew his kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'm now maſter of Ten thouſand pounds; I remember your old Maxim, Law for Money; and if it hold, you'll add another Ten to't.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Look ye now, the Rogue has me already on the ſore hip—Ned, Ned, why Ned, I am thy Uncle, and thy beſt friend; I've a great kindneſs for thee, and wou'd not willingly put thee to charges: baniſh, my dear boy Ned, all thoughts of Law, and live happy with thy preſent fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: No diſputes on a bridal night, the buſineſs ſhall be amicably compos'd at another time.

div.stage: Enter Freelove, and Lucy, Decoy following.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Now, now look ye; whom have we here? if he's one of Ned's Companions, he's a Rogue, and ſhe a Jilt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I wiſh you much Joy, and you, fair Ladies; I was inform'd of your good fortunes, and cou'd be no longer abſent; I'm happy too, and bleſt as you are.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, Sir, is a Gentleman, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You're very welcome, Sir; Body o' me, my Son • in-Law's friend is no leſs than a Member of my family, and may confidently claim my Service.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sir, I'm your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, he has got a delicate Wench, wou'd I had married her.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: How long, Freelove, haſt thou been acquainted with this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Not above two days; 'twas by Madam De • c • ys means I had the good fortune to be belov'd, and Marriage ſoon follow'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Then, Jack, thou art abus'd, I know her Circumſtances, and can aſſure thee ſhe is not Miſtreſs of a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Kind heaven bleſs me with the gift of patience, I m ruin'd, Fortune has done her worſt; and in be • raying others, I've undone my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p:
Thou too art cheated; but to ſalve this • ore, ••• e give thee a th • uſand pounds, and one hundred yearly during thy 〈◊〉 : forget Sir John 〈◊〉
and the follies of thy younger years; be Juſt to thy husband, and in ſo doing thou art kind to thy ſelf and me—in the mean time, Madam D • c • y has us'd you unkindly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She has my Bond too for a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By heaven, and mine too.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Theſe Bonds, Madam, won't be allow'd of by a Judge; and to evite further trouble, 'tis fitting you ſhou'd reſtore them.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: O dear Sir, two thouſand pounds! I deſerve them very well.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Pillory you mean, Madam.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I ſcorn your words; I'm an honeſt Woman, and won't be ſo abus'd, I do every thing above board, and—and—

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: You did aſſiſt me in my Love, and therefore I'm your friend; give up the Bonds, and I'll give you a Bill of fifty pounds upon my Goldſmith in Chea • ſide.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Well, Sir, my duty binds me to obedience; and rather than loſe your friendſhip, I'll do't.

div.stage: [Gives the Bonds, and they tare off their Names.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come aw • u me Jo, be me Saul we ſall be aus merry aus fifty beggars aut au fair; this letter will gau • me new Maiſter loup out o' his skin for faunneſs, baut ſpeak o' the meekle deel, aun yer be ſure to ſtaurt him—hea Sir, read th • ut, aun ſee whaut it ſays tea ye yer aul Aunt is aus deed aus au herring, aun hes left ye au her geer.

sp.speaker: B •• .
sp.p: Well, Sir John, I hope you'll remember me now I'm marry'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Are you her husband? Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A goad am I Sirrah, thea Engliſh men hea na breeding, ſhame fau me gin they ſou'd na gang to Holland to learn it.—But whaut a vengeance is the matter we me Maiſter, has the aul wutch geen him the wraung ſow be the lug, I woner?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: It is ſo, good and bad news come together.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Then Fortune is Juſt; thou art not, Jack, beholding to thy wife for all, for now thou haſt brought thy ſhare—now Joy ſhall ſhine in every face, and Muſick ſhall elevate the Soul to mirth; let the thoughts of buſineſs for a while be ſuſpended, and Love the only end of all our actions.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then body o' me Mr. Chorus ſhall give us a Song: Dick call him in preſently.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo, Sir-father, I'll ſing a Song firſt, I learn't it of my Landlady's daughter at the Swan, who had the Child by young Hobs the Carrier.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: With all my heart boy; Sincerely I'm glad to ſee thee ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: Rogues, Villains, they will be all hang'd

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Hem, hem, by Jupiter I have a very good pipe upon occaſion.

div.p: Now, Sir-father, how d'ye like it? by Apollo I ſung it very well.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I wull gee au Scotlaun Dance worth fourty o't, baut I waunt a piper.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Violin, Sirrah, is better.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Play up thaun Fidlers, aun be haung't tea ye, aut let me hea au
• erray bonny Spring.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Now let's have another Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: And as tha • ends, let the Dance begin.

div.p:
Now, Gentlemen, let's take another Road to Pleaſure, change the Scene of mirth, and in the next Room (larger than this, and fitted for the purpoſe)
• oſs a Eumper.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Uds ſo.

q.l: Wine pleaſure brings, and Care deſtroys,
It new creates the Soul for Joys; Ta • la-ra, ta tal fa-la.

div.p: I've loſt my Miſtreſs; but by Jupiter I'm 〈…〉 to be merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Body o' me, thou'rt in 〈…〉 Boy—Come, Neighbour Chollerick▪
••• get and forgive, as the ſaying is: Sincerely, who knows but I may live to get another Daughter for ye?

sp.speaker: Choll.
sp.p: No matter, let Ned, and that Jilt be hang'd; let the reſt of the Rogues be—But ſtay; I will drink with them before I go.

div.stage: [Is running off in a paſſion, and returns ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then, Gentlemen, let's go in.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p:
This day has repair'd all our Sufferings paſt, and we may ſafely now, without vanity, believe our ſelves belov'd, if Youth (e're Judgment •
ſtrong) knew all the Joys, the true content, and peace of mind, which honeſt Love rewarded can beſtow, they'd envy our happineſs, and contemn that uncertain ſtate of life, which inſtead of pleaſure, gives continued pains.

q.l: Love and Ambition, ſomething are a-kin;
But mighty Love is ſtill the nobler Sin;
It wakes the ſleeping Soul, and makes it ſtill
Seek greater Goods than purblind Reaſon will.
We covet nothing, when we all poſſeſs;
Our Joys wax greater, and our Fears grow leſs;
And laſting Pleaſures with our Years encreaſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE:
Spoke by WILL. PINKETHMAN.
div.l: YOur Favour's the Reward, I and the Author—
O, ſtay, no—
The Author and I do jointly ſeek it;
He finds the Wit, and I—the face to ſpeak it:
And that we may ſucceed in our Deſign,
I come to Court you—arm'd with Wit and Wine.
The Fair alone from this Device will ſhrink;
For as they never Hiſs, they never Drink
—in Publick:
Yet theſe are th' terms (the Author's ſuch a Fop)
If you don't Hiſs—I muſt not Taſte a drop.
Then, Friendly Sirs, be to your Servant juſt,
And Damn the Epilogue to Quench my Thirſt.

〈…〉
• ulneſs ſo wou'd mutter,
I ſhou'd not 〈◊〉 Bottle after Supper—
What not yet, are all againſt me bent▪
Egad, I'll take your Silence for Conſent.
—I dare not venture:
O, ſo—very well—
very well:
Nay! Now once more—
Will. Pinkethman begs you to be Civil;
To have Wine by one, and not drink's, the Devil.
You're all Good-natur'd if you're Croſs to night,
For tho' the Wit is Counterfeit, the Wine is right.
But now for the Epilogue— Egad this is not the
Paper! What ſhall I do! Let me ſee if I can
remem ••• it—Ha! hum! No; well
I'll ſpeak one of my Own.—
But now I think on't, his is very Pretty;
And I'm afraid I ſhan't be half ſo Witty:
So if you'll ſtay till I go find the right,
I'll read it now—Elſe call to morrow night.
But hold!
I've ſomething now of Conſequence to ſay,
Good ſimple Bays on me beſtows his Play;
Therefore, dear Friends, come all on the Third Day.
If not to him, to me your Favour ſhow,
And think on poor Will Pinkethman; for you muſt know,
Your Long Vacations make him very Low.
And now the Fatal time is Drawing on,
When you will all Forſake this Charming Town,
And to the Country for Diverſion run.
The Gameſters, They to Epſom take their way;
And while they are with the City-Dames at play,
The Husband's Bowl their Coin and Cares away.
The Masks (Alas, poor Souls!) they muſt ſtay here,

And to the
• olly will in Sholes repair,
To feed on Cold ſtufft Beef, and drink ſtale Beer.
The Players; ay, they're left too in the Lurch;
Why, they muſt e'en go twice a Day to Church:
For ſince they're like to live upon the Air,
'Tis fit their Faſting ſhou'd be joyn'd with Pray'r.
